ALLEGATION:
The foster care worker is aware that two youths in the foster home have had
incidents of sexually inappropriate behavior with one another and failed to implement
safety planning.
2

INVESTIGATION:
On 8/22/2022 I reviewed the complaint which indicated the above. It also indicated:
• The foster parents have been bathing the foster youths together and the
children continue to share a bed.
• There have been difficulties working with foster care.
On 8/22/2022 I also spoke with the Complainant by telephone. The Complainant
confirmed the information in the complaint. The Complainant reported speaking with
Foster Parent A about a children service complaint that had been received and the
information indicated in this complaint was revealed. Foster Parent A reported
having some difficulty working with the agency worker. The specific of those
difficulties was not indicated by the Complainant. The foster parent reported
concerns about Child C’s and Child D’s behavior. That Child C and Child D have
been touching each other during bath time. The foster parent reported the agency is
aware of these behaviors. The Complainant asked Foster Parent A whether a safety
plan had been completed by the agency related to the sexually inappropriate
behaviors and Foster Parent A did not seem to know what a safety plan was. The
Complainant reported Foster Parent A indicated Child C and Child D had reported
seeing their father sexually maltreating their sister. The reporting by the Child C and
Child D seemed to have occurred after Foster Parent A was questioning them.
Complainant advised Foster Parent A to stop questioning the girls about those
things. Foster Parent A reported not wanting to be a therapist, but reported she is
not getting guidance on what to do about the girls’ behaviors
Onsite agency visit
On 8/24/2022 I made an onsite visit to the Children’s Center agency. At that time, I
met with Administrator 2, Program Manager 3, and Quality Representatives 4 related
to the complaint allegations. I also interviewed Supervisor 5, and Foster Care
Worker (FCW) 6. The agency affirmed that there are three foster children in Case X
which this complaint relates. The children are Child C (age 4), Child D (age 6) and
Child E (age 11). Child C and Child D are placed with Foster Parent A and Foster
Parent B, who are Children Center licensed foster parents. Child E is in placement
with Caregiver R. The agency denied prior awareness of the information in the
complaint. They recently became aware, when FCW 6 discovered such after a late
August 2022 foster home visit.
Supervisor 5
Supervisor 5 reported being the current supervisor for Case X. She also served in
the capacity of FCW for the case prior to FCW 6’s assignment to the case on
8/4/2022.
Supervisor 5 reported aside from the foster parents bringing to her attention, on
7/30/2022, an incident of Child C gyrating on a belt between her legs, she was
unaware of sexual inappropriate behavior between the girls. At a 7/30/2022 foster
home visit, Supervisor 5 reported discussing pediatric masturbation with the foster
3

parents; and she advised them not to shame Child C. She also later provided them
literature on this behavior to help them with handling the behavior.
Supervisor 5 reported it was not until after FCW 6’s visit to the foster home on
8/20/2022 that Supervisor 5 became aware of the sexual behavior between Child C
and Child D, and them being bathed together. FCW 6 informed Supervisor 5 that
the foster parents reported when Child C and Child D were in the tub, they made
sexually inappropriate gestures to one another. Supervisor 5 did not know the
specifics of those gestures, whether that information was elaborated on by the foster
parents. Supervisor 5 reported that at the 8/20/2022 home visit, FCW 6 told the
foster parents to stop bathing Child C and Child D together; and to change/dress the
children separately.
Supervisor 5 reported only becoming aware of the Child C and Child D sharing the
same bed on 8/23/2022 during a telephone call with Foster Parent A. The purpose
of the call was to express to Foster Parent A what more the agency could do to
formalize a safety plan. During that telephone call Foster Parent, A shared that
Foster Parent A puts Child C and Child D in the same bed to sleep. Foster Parent A
reported the girls had always slept together during their placement with Caregiver W;
and they continued that practice. Supervisor 5 advised Foster Parent A that as a
foster parent they must abide by departmental rules on children having their own
bed, that Foster Parent A must not do what the relative had done by allowing the
girls to share a bed. Supervisor 5 said she advised Foster Parent A of Foster A’s
and Foster Parent B’s need to check on Child C and Child D through the night.
Further, that if one or the other of the girls get up and get in the other’s bed, to
remove the child and place her back in her own bed. Supervisor 5 also suggested
to Foster Parent A that since the family has an extra room, to allow the girls to have
separate rooms. The agency had planned to put the latter suggestion into the safety
plan, but Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B did not like that and refused use the
extra room. Therefore, the agency suggested putting the girls’ beds in a way that
they are side to side but not so together.
Supervisor 5 advised that the reason the agency did not know about Child C and
Child D sharing a bed, is because each child has a twin size bed; and during
monthly foster home visits they saw separate beds. Also, the foster parents had not
disclosed that the girls share a bed.
Foster Care Worker 6
Foster Care Worker (FCW) 6 reported shadowing Supervisor 5 on Case X from June
of 2022 until she assumed case responsibility in August 2022. She affirmed
information reported by Supervisor 5 related to FCW 6’s contacts and efforts related
to the 8/20/2022 foster home visit. FCW 6 reported asking Foster Parent B during
that home visit whether there had been any children services complaint, and Foster
Parent B responded, no, but indicated Foster Parent A (who was away during FCW
6’s home visit) did a reporting because Child C and Child D were sexually acting out
with each other at bath time. Foster Parent B was not sure why Foster Parent A
4

contacted children services as opposed to the agency. FCW 6 reported prior to this
August home visit she did not know that girls were acting out sexually or bathing
together. She reported per her review of the case, she did not recall seeing anything
about the Child C and Child D having sexually acting out behaviors. At this home
visit FCW 6 told the foster parent to give the children separate baths starting
immediately. She also advised that the girls may need to sleep in different rooms;
should dress separately, and that a safety plan will need to be in place. FCW 6
documented all this information, informed Supervisor 5 of the situation, and inquired
about completing a safety plan. FCW 6 said she was advised to complete a safety
plan by Monday (8/22/2022). The agency provided me a copy of that subsequent
safety plan.
Foster Parent A & Foster Parent B
Foster Parent A was interviewed by me by telephone on 9/12/2022. Foster Parent B
was in the background and Foster Parent A could be heard asking him for answers
to some of my questions as I spoke with Foster Parent A. Foster Parent A reported
they were Child C’s and Child D’s approved substitute care providers. They were
also the girls respite care providers. The girls lived with them part time and were at
one time in the home five nights on and five night off” from January 2022 until the
girls were officially placed in their home following their licensure in April 2022.
Foster Parent A reported they have been reporting information about the girls
inappropriate behaviors going back to 1/14/2022, during the time FCW 7 was the
worker. Foster Parent A reported they would compile things that was happening
with the girls by way of their telephone. For example, on 1/14/2022 they informed
FCW 7 that Child C was playing with the dog’s butt. Foster Parent A stated FCW 7
made a statement something like “in foster care you see stuff like this. Foster Parent
A perceived that statement as the FCW brushing the incident off. Foster Parent A
admitted that FCW may have suggested something, as to what to do. What that
FCW “thought was helpful”, but Foster Parent A could not recall the suggestion.
Foster Parent A reported on 1/16/2022 she was rubbing one of the girl’s stomachs,
and the child was motioning her towards the child’s private area. The sister was
giving a thumbs up while Foster Parent A was rubbing the child’s belly. On
2/9/2022 they disclosed to the worker that Child C had the car seat near her vagina
area and was humping it. Foster Parent A reported not knowing whether they were
reporting all the incidents in real time. They were just documenting the incidents on
their phone, but they had made several incident reports to the agency prior to this
complaint. Those were inclusive of Child D trying to ‘grind” on Child C’s body on
8/4/2022, which they told the agency about. Foster Parent A reported Child C and
Child D were not constantly acting out sexually; nor were they sexually acting out at
bedtime. The girls only did so at bath time, or when they did not have their clothes
on. Foster Parent A admits the girls were sleeping in the same bed and were being
bathed together. The latter of which she said the agency only told her was not
permitted three weeks prior to her interview with me. She admitted she and Foster
Parent B may not have disclosed that Child C and Child D shared a bed or were
bathed together. The agency workers may have assumed Child C and Child D slept
5

in different beds, because each child has her own; and during home visits the
workers would have seen two beds. Foster Parent A reported they allowed Child C
and Child D to share a bed, because Child C and Child D had done so when in
placement with Caregiver W; and they continued that. Notwithstanding this, Foster
Parent A reported the agency still knew information because Foster Parent A
reported it during Child C’s and Child D’s Image Center’s intake and evaluation in
January 2022. The information would have been in the psychological report that was
completed by the Image Center. Foster Parent A reported they just wanted
assistance with the behaviors Child C and Child D were displaying. They did not
know anything about a safety plan until the children services person asked them
about a safety plan after Foster Parent A shared information about the girls bathing
together. Foster Parent A reported when she shared with the agency that Child C
was humping the car seat, the worker told them that’s behavior that comes out
during the discovery phase of placement. Foster Parent A reported they are new
foster parents, the agency are rule followers, so if she and Foster Parent B were
doing anything inappropriate they expected the agency would tell them. She
indicated they reached out to their foster parent navigator because they had no
services in place for the girls and were not sure of what to do.
Reviewed
A review of Child C’s and Child D’s case records showed:
Child C and Child D were placed with the agency on 9/23/2021; at which time they
were in the care of Caregiver W. The children were placement with Foster Parent A
and Foster Parent B on 4/8/2022, following prior respite visits, inclusive of an
extended visit on 3/31/2022.
The Imagine Center for Psychological Health report dated 4/12/2022 following a
1/26/2022 and 3/22/2022 evaluation date that showed the following outcome related
to both Child C and Child D:
• On one occasion, Foster Parent A was tickling Child C and Child D gave her
a thumbs up when asked what that meant Child C began rubbing her thumb
inappropriately (what Child C specially did with her thumb was not indicated in
the psychological report). That Child C and Child D may walk around
slapping their private parts, may look in a mirror inappropriately; she and her
sister have touched each other’s private parts.
• Diagnostic Impressions included Reactive attachment disorder, Post
traumatic stress disorder, attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, combined
presentation (provisional) for both Child C and Child D.
• Recommendations included educational, and or speech, occupational or
psychological therapy follow up services for both Child C and Child D related
to their specific area of needs as specifically indicated in each child’s
psychological report. If such concerns emerged then psychology/social work
services, as well as private case management services, including caregiver
supports, family counseling/therapy, and respite care were also
recommended.
6

• The family was referred to The Easter Seals of Michigan for services.
Continued consultation with the treating physician and a reevaluation in 12
months of intervention was also strongly recommended.
Social Work Contacts from 1/26/2022 to 8/20/2022 for caregiver home visits which
showed:
• Home visits with Child C, Child D, and the relative caregiver, Caregiver W
held on 1/26/2022, 2/24/2022 and 3/24/2022. Child C, Child D and Caregiver
W were interacted with/spoken to and the girls bedroom was seen. No safety
concerns were documented.
• Home visits to Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B’s home on 4/27/2022,
5/26/2022(via window observation and facetime due to COVID issues)
6/15/2022(virtually due to COVID), 7/30/2022 and 8/20/2022. Each of these
visits indicated the children’s bedroom room was seen and denoted
interaction with the children and foster parents. The 4/27/2022 and 7/30/2022
social work contact indicated no safety concerns reported.
• The 5/26/2022 social work contact indicated a case update was provided to
the foster parent. It indicated the agency became aware that the court
ordered therapy, and also ordered parenting time with the birth father.
Additionally, that the foster parent reported concerns with the girls’ behaviors,
(what those behaviors were was not documented).
• The 6/15/2022 social work contact indicated the foster parents reported the
children have been displaying really inappropriate behavior. That these
behaviors gives the caregiver concerns due to maltreatment being unknown
for Child C and Child D. That Foster Parent A reported that Child C has asked
men to show her their private parts; and Child C has been seen touching
herself in front of male company. This social work contact did not indicate
what, if anything the worker offered to the foster parents related to Child Cs’
reported behaviors.
• The 7/30/2022 social work contact did not indicate inappropriate behavior
concerns but indicated “No new behaviors are being demonstrated by either
child”. This case note did not spell out what the prior behaviors were.
• The 8/20/2022 social contact indicated Foster Parent B was seen in the foster
home with Child C and Child D. That Foster Parent A was out of town. Foster
Parent B reported wanting more help with the children’s behaviors. He
reported needing “more resources like how to handle trauma/what to do, help
with the things they should know...some guidance." Additionally, that there
was discussion about whether any children protective services complaints
had occurred since the last visit, and Foster Parent B reported Foster Parent
A was advised by an unnamed person to make a complaint regarding sexual
behaviors occurring between the girls during bath time. This social work
contact also documented information reported by FCW 6 as reported during
FCW 6’s interview with me related to what she advised the foster parent; and
the agency completing a safety plan thereafter.
7

A review of caregiver home visit sheets provided to me by the agency for 1/26/2022,
3/24/2022; 4/27/2022, 7/30/2022; and 8/20/2022 showed information similar to what the
MISACWIS case work contact reported.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
(3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
directly responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care.
Social service workers shall work directly with the children,
their families, and other relevant individuals and be
primarily responsible for the development, implementation,
and review of service plans for the children and their
families.
ANALYSIS: The evidence showed the agency staff knew or should have
known on or about 4/27/2022(at the time of a family team
meeting related to the children’s replacement) if not sooner that
Child C and Child D were displaying inappropriate acting out
behaviors, some of a sexual nature. This is because some of
those behaviors were indicated in a psychological report
completed 4/12/2022. Sexually acting out behaviors, more
specific to Child C was also reported by the foster parents
during a home visit on 6/15/2022.
Some of these behaviors were reported during the time Foster
Parent A and Foster Parent B were providing respite care/ prior
to the Child C’s and Child D’s placement in the couple’s newly
licensed foster home on 4/8/2022. The behaviors were ones
Foster Parent A, and Foster Parent B were dealing with and
needed assistance with before and after the official placement
date, and safety planning did not occur with the foster family
until 8/20/2022.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
The foster care agency has not engaged the youths in needed therapy yet.
INVESTIGATION:
Complainant
On 8/22/2022 I reviewed the complaint and spoke with the Complainant by
telephone. The Complainant reported it was shared with them by Foster Parent A
that the children in the home foster home are in need of mental health services.
Additionally, that the agency reports they are working on said service, but the extent
8

of those efforts are unknown. The Complainant reported there may be delays in
getting said service due to therapeutic wait lists. The Complainant reported Foster
Parent A reported not wanting to be a therapist, but reported she is not getting
guidance on what to do about the girls behaviors.
Onsite agency visit
On 8/24/2022 I made an onsite visit to the Children’s Center agency. At that time, I
met with Administrator 2, Program Manager 3, and Quality Representatives 4 related
to the complaint allegations. I also interviewed Supervisor 5, and Foster Care
Worker (FCW) 6.
Supervisor 5
Supervisor 5 reported sometime after the children entered care with the agency on
9/23/2021, the court ordered mental health services for the children. She advised
that the children live in Macomb County; and the agency has made various efforts to
secure the services. Various barriers occurred due to the children’s Medicaid,
several providers not being available due a clinician shortage in Michigan, and
thereby causing a shortage of slots for clinical services. Supervisor 5 reported in
July 2022, the court order family therapy and the agency ran into a barrier with
getting this service squared away. Supervisor 5 reported this was due to the fact that
the children reside in Macomb, JAC (Juvenile Assessment Center) services are via
Wayne County and historically the child’s Medicaid has been tied to county of
residence. Meaning services must occur in that county of residence. She indicated
the agency initiated a JAC referral for said services on 7/21/2022; and as of recent
the JAC indicated they can provide some services. As of 8/16/2022 the JAC
indicated they could not provide Infant Mental Health (IMH) services for Child C and
Child D, but they can provide regular individual therapy. A separate referral for each
child was required. FCW 6 completed the referral on 8/23/2022 and Supervisor 5
said she submitted it to the department on 8/24/2022.
Supervisor 5 reported Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B were well aware of the of
the problems with therapy referrals, because it was explained to them throughout.
Additionally, the foster parents were also in attendance at the court hearings where
these issues and barriers were discussed.
Foster Care Worker 6
As reported elsewhere in this report, FCW 6 is relatively new to Case X. She
affirmed Supervisor 5’ reporting related to there not being many infant mental
services available. She also relayed that to Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B;
and that the agency would keep the family informed of the progress on therapy
efforts. FCW 6 reported being responsible for completion of updated JAC referral
which she reported making today (8/24/2022).
Foster Parent A
Foster Parent A was interviewed by me via telephone on 9/12/222. She reported
they have asked about services for Child C and Child D for a long time. She
9

acknowledged the agency advised them of the referral process, lack of therapists,
and wait list pertaining to therapeutic services. Foster Parent A reported they
understand wait lists, but they still had concerns and questioned a continued delay
with these services since the children have been in care for over year. Foster Parent
A reported “it is just taking a long time”. She reported the agency did try to assist
them with referrals, by suggesting they call this program or that one; but the agency
was not making those calls. She reported the agency has gotten Child C and Child
D into family therapy with their birth mother. The agency thought that might help, but
individual service are still pending. Three week prior, the agency advised that Child
C and Child D would get individual therapy through the same therapist they are
seeing for family therapy.
Reviewed
A review of Child C’s and Child D’s case records showed:
• The agency completed a referral for psychological assessment and services for
the children via Imagine for Psychological Health Center on 10/27/2021.
Additionally, via that assessment that provider referred the foster parents to
Easter Seals for other possible services
• The agency also completed a referral for services, in November 2021, then again
on 7/21/2022 and lastly on 8/23/2022.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
(3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
directly responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care.
Social service workers shall work directly with the children,
their families, and other relevant individuals and be
primarily responsible for the development, implementation,
and review of service plans for the children and their
families.
10

ANALYSIS: There is insufficient evidence to support a lack of direct work
with the foster family and resource providers related to services
for the children. A lack of resources and therapist availability
impacted the agency’s ability to secure timely individual
therapeutic services for the children. Those barriers have now
been worked though. The children are reported to be in line to
receive said service via the JAC, as an adjunct to the family
therapy.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
The foster care worker is monitoring multiple visits at once and not appropriately
supervising.
The foster parent is being mandated to travel extensively for parenting visit.
INVESTIGATION:
Complainant
I spoke with the complainant about this allegation via telephone on 8/22/2022. The
Complainant reported it was reported that the FCW is conducting parent/child visits
for the birth mother via Zoom, while simultaneously supervising another parent/child
visit over Zoom.
The Complainant affirmed the allegation in the complaint statement. Further, that the
foster parent expressed a concern related to transporting Child C and Child D to
parenting visits which are reportedly two hours away. That it is alleged the agency is
not willing to work with the foster parents; and the FCW told Foster Parent A the
department “does not care about how far away visits are”. Additionally, that the
FCW told the foster parents it is their responsibility to transport to and from visits;
and the agency has no regard for the foster parents’ schedule or how inconvenient it
is for them.
Onsite agency visit
On 8/24/2022 I made an onsite visit to the Children’s Center agency. At that time, I
met with administrative staff as listed prior about these allegations. I also interviewed
Supervisor 5, and FCW 6.
Supervisor 5 & FCW 6
Supervisor 5 and FCW 6 denied the allegations.
Supervisor 5 reported:
• Visitation for the children’s birth mother occurs in the agency’s office, face to
face not Zoom. That at times, a worker may be supervising another visit
during an office time, but in those instances, the worker is positioned in such
a way she is directly aside both rooms and can observe both. Additionally,
11

there are times visits occur by use of rooms with two-way mirrors. In those
instances, the worker is only supervising that visit, at that time. Supervisor 5
was not sure why someone would make this allegation; but reported an
awareness of the foster parents not being happy that the court has ordered
Zoom or telephone visitation for Child C and Child D with their birth father.
The agency is aware Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B have a
demanding schedule and that’s why the agency has made accommodations
with and for them. Therefore, workers will go out on Saturday because that
works best for the foster parents.
• Parenting visits for Child C and Child D, nor sibling visits are two hours way.
Nor has she or an agency staff told Foster Parent A and or Foster Parent B
the Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) does not care about
the distant of visits. She/the agency explained to the foster parents about
travel/mileage and visitation time requirement by the department based on
the age of the children.
When Case X was with DHHS, DHHS was transporting the children from
their placements to the DHHS office for visits. When the case transferred to
the Children’s Center on 9/23/2021, the Children’s Center continued that
transportation support practice. The agency transported to a meeting/drop off
point (unless the person couldn’t do so, and then the Children’s Center would
transport the whole way). That in the earlier months of Child C’s and Child
D’s placement, they were with Caregiver W, and Caregiver W utilized Foster
Parent A and Foster Parent B for transportation. Therefore, Foster Parent A
and Foster Parent B have been aware of transportation responsibilities on
this case. Additionally, Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B have never
requested transportation assistant, nor complained about it to Supervisor 5.
The agency has provided the foster parents documents they can use to
request mileage reimbursement related to transportation.
For now, with sibling visitation, both caregivers reside in Macomb County. As
for parenting visitation, the birth mother visits occur at the office; and to
minimize transportation travels, the agency has scheduled sibling visits
weekly on the same day as the birth mother’s visit. That it was just recently
that the court ordered Zoom or telephone visitation by the birth father, and
Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B voiced upset on that. The foster parents
do not want the birth father to have their telephone number or for their home
to be exposed. The agency is still exploring a way to facilitate the birth
father/children visits without the foster parent being comprised in any way.
FCW 6 reported:
• Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B were Child C’s and Child’s D’s
substitute care provider from Caregiver W’s neighborhood. The foster
parents seemed more abreast of some things about the girls than the
12

agency. Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B participated in the April 2022
FTM placement change about the girls, where services and transportation
needs were discussed and shared with them. She explained to the foster
parents that Child C and Child D have a right to Zoom visit with their birth
father, and Foster Parent B said he was not going to do that. FCW 6
reported the agency was still working this out with the foster parents.
Her supervision of parent/child visits have been with the birth mother and
children. These visit have not been via Zoom but are in a visitation room. She
monitors these visits via a two-way mirror. Since her assignment on this
case, she has supervised four parent/child visits and there was never a time
where she supervisor another visit at the same time. Additionally, the Zoom
visits with the children’s birth father are pending; efforts need to be work
through.
• Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B seemed to be under the impression
that Child C and Child D would become permanent wards, because the
children initially entered foster care under an original permanent custody
petition. The foster parents are very new; Child C and Child D are their first
